title: Do I list money given by family where there was no promissory note in Chapter 7?
question: Over the years I have received money from family. There were never any promissory notes signed or terms given and I have never made a payment back to them.
answers: If it is a no asset case it won’t make any difference but you are supposed to list all creditors regardless

ALL debts need to be listed. If there was an expectation of repayment then it is not a gift and should be listed. If there was no expectation of repaying then it is a gift and need not be listed as a debt.

That said, if there is any chance that someone will seek repayment you might as well list it as a debt. Then it will clearly be covered by your discharge and your (lack of) legal obligation will be clear. You can always choose to pay your family back after your bankruptcy is over even if you are not legally obligated to do so.

Remember you can always pay it back later, even if the debt is discharged in bankruptcy.

The remainder of this message is for any other consumer who may be reading this response:

The real question is why are you trying to fill out a bankruptcy petition on your own? That is the real mistake and although you feel you are saving money now, you may wish you had a lawyer later when something weird happens.

There are things that cannot be undone once you file a Chapter 7 petition. Many have come to regret doing it without an attorney who understands the other Chapters and what the big picture is all about.

If the money was given to you with some expectation of repayment in the future, then it's a loan. You would need to disclose that on your schedule F. If the money was given to you with no expectation of repayment whatsoever, then it's a gift. You wouldn't need to list it as a loan, but it could be considered income you might need to disclose, depending on when it was received and whether the amounts were received with any regularity.
